basics.name: Varuna Jasodanand
basics.label: PhD Candidate
basics.summary: PhD student in Behavioral Neurosciences at Boston University, leveraging AI and machine learning for Alzheimer's disease research, neuroimaging analysis, and computational biology.

work.name: Boston University, Kolachalama Laboratory
highlights: Leveraging AI-based frameworks for diagnosis and staging of biological Alzheimer's disease.
Developing computer vision models for clinically relevant neuroimaging data representation.
Applying survival models to proteomics data to identify novel prognostic protein biomarkers.
Implementing and evaluating large language models for neurology applications.

work.name: Novartis Biomedical Research, Human Genetics & Targets
work.summary: Co-mentors: Dr. Sarah Spencer, Dr. Andrea Byrnes, Dr. Victoria Eastham
highlights: Developed a reusable, version-controlled pipeline integrating internal and external multi-omics data for systematic target identification and prioritization.
Deployed a Dash-based web application with dynamic data tables enabling cross-functional teams to evaluate and prioritize therapeutic targets.

work.name: Vanderbilt University, Vanderbilt Memory and Alzheimer's Center
work.summary: Co-PIs: Dr. Angela Jefferson, Dr. Timothy Hohman
highlights: Examined the relationship between cardiovascular health and brain aging.
Built preprocessing and analysis pipelines for multimodal neuroimaging and clinical data.

work.name: Bryn Mawr College, Grafe Laboratory
highlights: Analyzed behavioral and EEG data to study sex differences in stress-induced sleep impairments in rats.
Conducted behavioral tasks and used cryosectioning and immunohistochemistry to assess cognitive flexibility and stress resilience.

work.name: University of Pennsylvania, Center for Neuromodulation in Depression and Stress
highlights: Supported recruitment efforts, collection of psychophysiological data, neuroimaging data quality check and clinical data organization using UNIX shell scripting.
Conducted statistical analyses on the effects of individualized transcranial magnetic stimulation on mood in major depressive disorder.

education.area: Calculus I, General Chemistry I & II, Organic Chemistry I & II

awards.title: Clinical & Translation Science Institute Poster Award
awards.summary: Awarded first place for poster presentation at the 12th CTSI Symposium.

awards.title: Departmental Honors in Psychology and Philosophy
